We have seen that the Borel sets in

children.value: have all these properties. In this lecture we will show how to construct counterexamples for each of these principles. The proofs make essential use of the Axiom of Choice.
One of the most famous applications of

children.value: is Vitali’s construction of a non-Lebesgue measurable set.

Show that a Bernstein set is not Lebesgue measurable.
As mentioned before, the existence of arbitrary choice functions appears to be a rather strong assumption.  However, the weaker versions of

children.html: AC\ACAC

children.value: do not suffice to construct counterexamples as above.
constructed (though under a large cardinal assumption) a model of

children.html: ZF+DC\ZF+\DCZF+DC

children.value: in which every set of real numbers is Lebesgue measurable, has the Baire property, and has the perfect subset property.
